text: Nicknamed "Doomballs", these dangerous micro-replicas of the Doomsphere provide Doom-flayers with a potent but unpredictable power source.
Mechanical flaying is a complex business; a Doom-flayer’s parts need constant analysis to stay in sync and to maximise power.
Allows the Warlock Masters to 'plug-in' to their Doom-flayers, redirecting some of the Warp-energy to their own bodies.
What happens when you stick foldable blades onto the ones you already have? An inescapable maelstrom of screaming, agonising, flaying death! Ouch!
Equipping a Doom-flayer with a set of motorized whirling blades gives it the ability to deflect incoming projectiles.
Warpstone-powered incendiary devices triggered around the Doom-flayer are effective countermeasures against anything thrown at them... which is typically an awful lot!
The secret recipe for this black stone alloy results in blades that get sharper and sharper the more they cut and slash.
Similar to the Doomwheel's 'Meat Shields' technique, putrid flesh is used to assault the enemy’s senses as a method of distraction.
Rigorous testing has shown that penetrating these reinforced, serrated armour plates is near-impossible without damaging the penetrating weapon.
An iron ball of death is more effective the less it is dragged down by resistance – be that by wind, blood, flesh, or bone!
These components allow a cyclical energy transfer between the scurrying rats powering the Doomwheel and its Warpstone generator, leading to incredible power surges.
Adding these to a Doomwheel's Warpstone generator allows a Warlock Master to overcharge its power output to unpredictable levels.
A portable power system used for keeping other Doomwheel systems operational when the scurrying rats are at full automotive capacity.
Allows Warp Lightning bolts to be split with a stunning 200% efficiency, using a technique likely 'acquired' from the Luminarks of Nuln.
Using these curiously-designed parts, power transfer can occur at impossible speeds, leading to even more devastating zappers.
Fitted to Doomwheel bolt-throwers, these allow Warp-energy to be briefly stored before firing, making for more concentrated attacks.
Smells like rat-bile mixed with crude oil, but few things are better for keeping engine parts moving – just don’t ask how it’s made.
These parts have long been scavenged from Dwarf-things' Gyrocopters – with modifications, they can also afford the Doomwheels more killing-mileage!
Blending metallurgy, alchemy, and sorcery results in the best armour you can possibly forge. Smells toxic, but what doesn't on a Doomwheel?
Tying up some slaves and suspending them around the Doomwheel provides some level of grisly protection – just keep the flesh fresh!
Research into new bullet designs yields interesting results; all that's needed now is an assembly line of slaves to painstakingly mass-produce them.
This new-fangled invention for ammunition replenishment enables on-the-spot conversion of metal scraps into bullets.
The hotter a Ratling Gun gets, the faster it can fire, but the more liable it is to overheat. Coolant solves this problem.
The Skaven do not have great eyesight, so the sniping ability of Warplock Jezzails benefits greatly from immensely powerful telescopic scopes.
A costly method of manufacturing bullets results in this all-purpose ammunition, effective against all types of armour whenever within killing range.
Invisibility is seemingly a step too far, so the Engineers of Skryre shall devise something they claim is just as good.
A giant labyrinth of pumps, valves, turbines, and generators, all submerged in an ominous cloud of green steam. Here, Warpstone’s power is harvested.
In the filthy caverns of the Under-Empire, the potential for mass destruction shall silently sit, stockpiled until the moment of explosive grandeur.
Devising new 'waste-not, want-not' methods will make even the most degraded or poisonous waste materials processable for Warp-fuel production.
Test subjects are prodded, stabbed, shot, zapped, burnt, dematerialised – you name it. If it causes pain or death, it probably happens here.
Warpstone ore is quite unusable in its crude state, needing processes of separation and purification before being in any way useful.
Give the Doomrockets an extra 'kick'. The enemy’s going to feel this one!
Larger enemy-things can endure globadiers' poisoned winds. But if laced with needle-thin Warpstone shards, even the thickest skin would provide no defence.
If Warpstone gas is passed through a Hell Pit Abomination before bottling, its potency increases dramatically. The specifics of this procedure are best left... undiscussed.
Bombardiers may be fragile, but the Wyrdstone fumes which envelop them are a powerful deterrent. With the right distillation, terror will grip any nearby foe.
The giddying effect of poisoned winds slows the work of Skaven mortar crews. Regularly inhaling these air-globes will grant fresh speed to tired paws.
Warpstone gas rakes flesh, but a strong mind might endure the agony unless the brew is infused with an unspeakable offal found only in the Plague Monks' rancid cells...
As if their lives were not already short and painful from exposure to poison winds, elite mortar crew are forced to stitch focus-enhancing Warpstone gems into their eyes.
A double-barrelled flamethrower has two uses – preventing the weapon from overheating and shooting enemies approaching from two different directions!
Whether handling dangerous materials in the lab or wielding chemical-spewing weaponry in the field, protective attire is always a boon!
With pump designs haphazardly copied from the Dwarfs, the Warpfire Throwers will squirt their toxic filth further than ever before!
When a Warpstone drillbit is flanged with pillaged Gromril, fashioned into crude rat-claw shapes, even the very rock is liquified by its unstoppable passage.
Legend tells that any Clanrat brave - or foolhardy - enough to snort this pain-blocking Warp-powder will see the face of the Horned Rat himself.
Given sufficient exposure to Warpstone spun at burning speeds, damaged Skaven flesh can knit itself back together. But only briefly. Stand clear when the effect fades…

Slitting the throats of their sleeping foes is one of the favoured nightly activities of all Eshin agents, useful for silently thinning out the ranks of enemy armies.\\n\\n[[col:yellow]]Damages an army for 10% of its current health.[[/col]]\\n\\n[[col:red]][[img:icon_turns]][[/img]]Agent recovery time: 2 turns[[/col]]

Although rival Lords can be hard to kill, a sneaky knife in the dark can always cause grievous injury.\\n\\n[[col:yellow]]Wounds the [[img:icon_general]][[/img]]Lord of a targeted army.[[/col]]\\n\\n[[col:red]][[img:icon_turns]][[/img]]Agent recovery time: 4 turns[[/col]]

Eshin's operatives are able to get into the most protected vaults, pulling off heists of unimaginable scale with surgical precision.\\n\\n[[col:yellow]]Steals up to {{tr:icon_money}}4000 from a settlement and reduces its income by 10% for 5 turns.[[/col]]\\n\\n[[col:red]][[img:icon_turns]][[/img]]Agent recovery time: 4 turns\\n[[img:icon_turns]][[/img]]Action cooldown time: 20 turns[[/col]]

Clan Eshin, though specialists in swift, sneaky deaths, are also able to sew discord amongst a population, mobilising its malcontents to run amuck.\\n\\n[[col:yellow]]Causes a rebellion in a settlement and reduces [[img:icon_public_order]][[/img]]control for 5 turns.[[/col]]\\n\\n[[col:red]][[img:icon_turns]][[/img]]Agent recovery time: 2 turns[[/col]]

Infiltrating an army’s ranks and stealthily turning individuals against each other is every Eshin agent’s idea of a fun soiree.\\n\\n[[col:yellow]]Applies [[img:icon_effect_morale]][[/img]]leadership penalty to a targeted army:[[/col]]

Eshin's murderous agents do not merely kill their enemies, for they are skilled in a whole range of espionage techniques, even able to take over other Skaven settlements.\\n\\n[[col:yellow]]Grants ownership over a Skaven settlement.\\n(Excludes [[img:icon_under_empire]][[/img]]Under-Cities)[[/col]]\\n\\n[[col:red]][[img:icon_turns]][[/img]]Agent recovery time: 4 turns[[/col]]

Snikch delights most in taking a sovereign’s head and watching their denizens stagger to destruction without direction or purpose.\\n\\n[[col:yellow]]Snikch removes a faction’s leader, causing them to be overthrown by rebels. Select any army or settlement to target a faction.[[/col]]\\n\\n[[col:red]][[img:icon_turns]][[/img]]Snikch recovery time: 5 turns\\n[[img:icon_turns]][[/img]]Action cooldown time: 100 turns[[/col]]

To ensure the agents of Clan Eshin do not falter in their unending, deadly tasks, additional rations are set aside for those assigned to carry out their nefarious schemes.\\n\\n[[col:yellow]]Resets all used [[img:skv_snikch_schemes]]Schemes.\\n(No target required)[[/col]]\\n\\n[[col:red]][[img:icon_turns]][[/img]]Action cooldown time: 10 turns[[/col]]

Though bringing death by stealth is Snikch's chief concern, he is also capable of blowing his opponents’ sea-based hardware clean out of existence.\\n\\n[[col:yellow]]Snikch destroys an [[img:icon_transport_fleet]][[/img]]army on sea.\\n(Includes Black Arks)[[/col]]\\n\\n[[col:red]][[img:icon_turns]][[/img]]Snikch recovery time: 5 turns\\n[[img:icon_turns]][[/img]]Action cooldown time: 50 turns[[/col]]

Snikch is a master arsonist, able to set fires that can rip right through an enemy city and leave nothing but ashes and charred bones in his terrible wake.\\n\\n[[col:yellow]]Snikch destroys all buildings in a settlement, leaving only the main settlement building behind.[[/col]]\\n\\n[[col:red]][[img:icon_turns]][[/img]]Snikch recovery time: 5 turns\\n[[img:icon_turns]][[/img]]Action cooldown time: 50 turns[[/col]]

Underhanded sneaky-scouting of a province provides otherwise hidden information of what’s there, even detecting the presence of rival warrens.\\n\\n[[col:yellow]]Grants vision of a province for 5 turns.\\n(Also reveals [[img:icon_under_empire]][[/img]]Under-Cities)[[/col]]

Snikch has all sorts of heinous weapons at his disposal, including a virulent, incurable contagion that can cripple a land’s population for an extended period.\\n\\n[[col:yellow]]Snikch's contagion stops recruitment, reduces [[img:icon_growth]][[/img]]growth and causes [[img:icon_attrition]][[/img]]attrition to local forces in a province.\\n\\n[[col:red]][[img:icon_turns]][[/img]]Snikch recovery time: 5 turns\\n[[img:icon_turns]][[/img]]Action cooldown time: 50 turns[[/col]]

On occasion, Eshin agents must steal food from other settlements – even stone-cold, hardened killers need to eat, you know!\\n\\n[[col:yellow]]Grants 5 [[img:icon_skaven_food]]food from a settlement.[[/col]]\\n\\n[[col:red]][[img:icon_turns]][[/img]]Action cooldown time: 10 turns[[/col]]

Shiny-shiny things of desire! Gold, or any other currency for that matter, is fair game to the agents of Eshin, especially when their oblivious targets aren’t looking.\\n\\n[[col:yellow]]Steals up to {{tr:icon_money}}1000 from a settlement and reduces its income by 10% for 5 turns.[[/col]]\\n\\n[[col:red]][[img:icon_turns]][[/img]]Action cooldown time: 10 turns[[/col]]

Amongst the Skaven, there's no such thing as getting ahead of Clan Eshin, whose eyes – and claws – are everywhere and nowhere at the same time.\\n\\n[[col:yellow]]Increases research rate by 20% for 5 turns. Additional applications increase effect duration.\\n(Targets Skaven settlements only)[[/col]]

The deeds of Tyrion in the Great Chaos Incursion shine as a beacon to the flower of Ulthuan’s fading nobility, gradually shaping the core of a resolute council.
The twin brothers know full well that their triumph begins with the restoration of tarnished glory, slab by slab of marble and serpentine set aright.
Though he is no great statesman, Tyrion is well versed in bringing out the greatest potential from those who march under his orders.
When ceremonial hierarchy is set in motion to bridle their obsessive bent, the Elven war host coalesces Asur single-mindedness into feats of discipline beyond mortal measure.

Word of mouth has spread with disastrous results. The will for war has inexplicably withered – all upon the veiled say-so of a certain someone.
Promises broken, oaths unfulfilled, all treaties torn up – but by whom? The one whose blood and breath carry all three like a contagion.
The hellish, maddening dimensions of the Daemon Realm open avenues of sight none but Sayl can traverse.
War is reasonably expected for those initiating it – except when it is initiated on their behalf, in a manner beyond any reason, and at a scale beyond all expectation.
Tricks of perspective and sudden unconscious piques of unease, as if someone – or something – descends upon Sayl's foes.
The madmen of rival minor tribes froth at the mouth in the shadows, too easily provoked by a careful sorcerous hand – and then carelessly scattered in the enemy's direction.
A little nudge in messages sent and received is all it needs. Any warrior will seize the chance to tarry and will the lie to become true.
Overexaggerated rumours of dissent are easily exposed as false. But in sowing discontent, the dose makes the poison. In this case, less is more.
Chaos slithers its way through the smallest cracks in reality. Even solid walls are rife with them. Enough for Sayl to see, seize, and sunder.
Through patience and a subtle tongue, Sayl lays down the foundations of subversion.
Sayl's voice is slickly sheened with hinted secrets and oleaginous half-truths. Yet at a brazen word, the poison hidden within sinks itself into a city's very foundations.
Anything earned is something to be parted with. The methods vary, but only because they are so abundant, as are the marks.
Every Chaos Warrior's ambition is to ascend to Daemonhood. As with much else, Sayl can grant them that – after a fashion.
Deceit may bring an army together, but material rewards keeps it together. Lies and magic can also achieve the former, more effectively – for a time.
The Winds of Magic are often fickle. Sorcerers resign themselves to such whims – none the wiser of Sayl's own fickleness in colluding with the flow of the Winds.
At their heart, all beings desire strife. Sayl provides the promise. The desire's fulfillment is left to the devices of those so lured.

The brute shades into the sapient by gradations so fine that there exists no sharp line of demarcation to set the boundaries of beasthood.
Concord with these disciples is born of reverence for unspoiled realms, where crags shelter the preying chill of Ghur, and brooks – the effervescent lifeblood of Ghyran.
Defiant of entropy, Ghyran mends wounds with unearthly swiftness; its vitalising sear hardens into a stratum of sinewed, porous tissue – a convergence of flesh and rind.
Not for Ghur the deliberate coalescing of stratagems, the simmering wrath of restraint; best a surge of feral vigour, a bout so sudden as to invite no further challenge.
Swelling with Amber Wind, the shadows of canopied hollows grow longer over time, attuning themselves to the feral sorcerer sheltering within.
Just as Ghyran ebbs and flows with the seasons, so too do its adherents grow lithe and vibrant in the throb of spring, and more sombre and still within the clasp of winter.
To invoke jade or amber is to draw upon primordial verdure, pulling at the elusive threads of their shared, untameable origin.
To alter the fraught currents of time is but the second greatest triumph of the Asuryan priesthood, surpassed only by their chronicling of fate.

Extraordinary is the union of insight and discipline ascetic, for such power alone may weave its threads upon the skeins of fate.
In the wan twilight of an age that had yet felt the tread of an Ithilmar-shod foot, these sorceries took primordial shape among the wilderness of Ulthuan.
Lo, the cynic shall proclaim: to summon the most ruinous of elements with the most precise of utterances is nought but a cruel jest of the cosmos.
Contemplations of mortal transience mark the meeting of Shyish and Ulgu, where the roiling shroud of uncertainty parts to unveil the solemn cycle beyond.
Burdened with the variegation of magic, the ensorceled wind whispers a wordless polyphony of arcana, for each attuned to divine as they will.

Infinitely layered by its ceaseless churn, the ground yawns open in intricate patterns not too dissimilar from the filigreed gates of Aqshy mastery.
The vortices of agitation, the knot of passion, the clenched fist of anger: surely there's a reason destruction always coils itself into a sphere.
Among the acolytes of the Yellow Wind and the Red there abides an unspoken accord, for there is no better expression of transfiguration than the flicker of the flame.
Unbridled by the cold restraint of reason, passionate resolve collapses into frenzy – devouring more and more, while yielding ever less.
As the heavy pall of ash chokes a raging blaze into feeble, smouldering embers, so too does Aqshy trail its own fervour with a weariness to match.
The brightness by which devotees of the Seventh Lore are known permeates every aspect of their being – from their quarrelsome debates to their all-consuming fury in battle.
Compelled to sift the measurable from every amorphous abstraction, followers of the Second Lore are naturally drawn to the labyrinths of mortal turmoil.
Transmutative Chamon find kinship in serpentine Aqshy, just as flame meets the tempered womb of the crucible and imparts to it a benevolent malleability.
